title: GSAP: Killer Web Animations With Cassie Evans

rawLines.text: Welcome to Syntax. Today we have a
really good one. We're going to be
talking with Cassie Evans, who is a
developer education over at Gap. So that
means we're going to be diving into all
about Gap, what it is, where it's at,
why you should be paying attention to
it, and just generally why it's so cool.
So Cassie, welcome to Syntax. How are
you? Hey. Yeah, I'm really good. I'm
very excited to to be on Syntax. Yeah.
Well, I'm excited to have you here. we
one, you know, we've been chatting for a
while uh just in general, but also GAP,
man, is one of those things that like
really feels like I I it's been a large
gap for me in my knowledge base. And so
I'm really excited to be able to just
really understand more. Um I think it's
a really exciting time to be talking to
you about this given uh some some news
that just happened and and in general, I
I think it's really cool. So yeah, very
very excited. Wes, how are you doing
today? I'm good. I'm I think maybe we
should go real quick into like what is
GAP for maybe anyone who who hasn't used
GAP before or maybe might not know what
it is. So, uh you want to give a stab at
what that is and then we'll we'll go
into the announcements and shortly after
that. Yeah, sure. So, um Gap is a very
powerful animation library um that you
can use to animate pretty much anything.
So, HTML elements or SVG or UI stuff, 3D
things, um, pretty much anything that
JavaScript can touch. And it's been
around for, woo, like 15 years now. So,
for the for the the people that have
been around since the Flash days,
they'll remember um, Gap as an action
script library. Um, so it's kind of been
like at the forefront of web animation
for a really long time now, man. And Gap
just had like a a major kind of
rebranding as as well, which was I think
great because for the longest time it
was like a that like superhero man and
it was extremely popular, but I think I
think a lot of people kind of wrote it
off as like that kind of whole vibe uh
lost it and the whole the new design
looks amazing. Were you part of that?
Yeah, that was um that was on my hit
list as soon as I started working at
GAP. One of the things about Jack, the
library author, is that he's very averse
to change, which when you are
maintaining a library that's used on
like 12 million websites, it's a good
thing. It's a really good thing. But I
think yeah, the the branding did need an
overhaul. I think it had it had a little
bit of um nostalgia for the Flash era
for people that were around, but like
the Gen Z youth, they didn't get the

Greenock Animation Platform. Um, but we

it was just kind of easier to just lean

just like green sock. I don't know think
about green socks. Uh Gap though the
branding on it rules. It looks great.
The landing page looks great. It all

just great looking. So uh I it it seems
so dumb to say that but I do feel like
I'm way more inclined to pick this up

Like what what makes Gap special? I

to learn, right? There's it's this it's

Gap is very performant under the hood

think the top ones would be animating
the wrong properties. And by wrong

would be like filters and box shadows.
filters are horrendous for her
animation. I think you sometimes see
people doing tricks with box shadows
where they have rather than animating
the properties of the box shadow itself,
they kind of animate the opacity of a

stuff like that. So yeah, it's good to
animate where you can transforms and

what's happening with your animations

background color just from transparent
to color. And the frame rate on the site

like this is so weird. And then sure
enough, I just did it with a after suda
selector and animated the opacity and
all of those issues went away. So
definitely important to know know those
things if uh uh it can get you into some
odd trouble sometimes for sure. Yeah, I
think as well like choosing the right

timelines are sequenced animations. So

understanding of other key frame blocks.
So if you've got, you know, two
animations and you want them to run one
